Bergita Bugarija
insight hunter, observer of culture, aspiring listener, maker of projects, the good husband’s wife, mother of two little dragons
Mar 6

Smiles are not (yet) free for all

The overlooked adoption curve of the American smiling culture

A smile can comfort, disarm, seduce, approve, excite, the list goes on. With such a range of capabilities it is one of the most powerful tools in the humanities’ nonverbal communication arsenal.

And yet while smiling is universal, the amount and meaning of smiling varies not only individually but more interestingly, culturally.

The map below, based on a Gallup study, shows at a glance where in the world people smile the most and least (if sloppily claiming that amount of smiling one does in a day also indicates more or less emotion -?!?).

When I asked the participants in my research from over 30 countries what were their initial observations of the US that stood out in comparison to where they came from, smiling came up as one of the most cited examples of a culture shock. But what could be so shocking about smiling? Smiles are free, aren’t they?

While in some cultures people smile more than in others, most agree that smiling is universally one of the most benevolent features of human behavior. Still, the meaning of smiling is more nuanced than this broad consensus leads on. Depending on the culture, circumstances, gender and so forth, smiles can also induce discomfort, confusion, distrust, annoyance.

Smiles in many places can even get you in trouble: if you are a smiling woman the intended friendliness could be easily mistaken for flirting, and for a man, a sign of weakness. Copious smiling can also signal various negative traits of the smiler: low intelligence and dishonesty are just some examples. The mistrust offset by a broad smile can lead to unwanted misunderstandings in the delicate world of diplomacy.

According to a number of immigrants I talked to, Americans smile — a lot! For the people from low smiling index countries (much of Eastern Europe, chunks of Middle and Far East and some African countries), American smiles at first seem excessive and fake: part of the superficial pleasantries emblazoned in the social interaction script or worse — a ploy tricking the unsuspected newcomer into the abyss of a hidden and likely not so benign agenda.

Here’s the sentiment in the words of one of the study participants:

There’s a lot of superficiality floating around. The need to appear nice bears on you. Everybody smiles at you but they probably think you’re an a-hole. It’s fake a lot of the time.

What is habitual in one culture, can be quite foreign to people from others — yet another skill to master on the path of acculturation. Like language, social cues are taught intuitively from the day we are born. And because a lot of people growing up outside the US haven’t exercised those smiling muscles nearly as vigorously prior to immigrating, getting used to smiling not only feels deeply unnatural but can be physically tiring.

Contrary to the popular saying, turns out there is more muscle work required for smiling than frowning after all. And just like we need to exercise any muscle to tone it, for smiles to develop stamina, fluidity and grace, takes ample time, modeling and practice.

The “bitchy resting face” stigma has been following me, as it has most any other immigrant from Eastern Europe. I remember when I was as a researcher first presenting studies to the clients in the US, my American boss would gush about the job well done while tactfully beseeching if only I could show a bit more enthusiasm. Read: smile! And here I was thinking that my seriousness would show how super professional I was and be evidence of the utmost respect for the important task I was entrusted with.

Here is another one of my interviewees with a bit of a first hand perspective that speaks to the possible origins of why serious is a mainstream facial expression in many cultures:

Life in Russia is much more stressful, the daily life and emotions that people express are polar opposite [to the US]. There is a lot of negativity, crime, bags being snatched. You get used to living in that environment so you’re never completely relaxed.
There are no people who smile at you in the street or say good morning. And if they do, they’re gonna look at you and think: are you nuts? and punch you in the face, like, what do you want from me? It’s a continuous social stress over something, crime, the economy.
They always ask why Russians don’t smile. What is there to smile about like an idiot? I adapted to smiling now. But there is no depth of understanding [from Americans]. If I don’t smile, it doesn’t mean that I’m a bitch. I hear it all the time: What are you mad about? I’m not, I’m just thinking, leave me alone.
Sometimes it feels like Americans don’t want to understand who Russians are, that person next to me who doesn’t smile. We’re just gonna make everyone smile like us. Which is easier to do, because when I started smiling I stopped getting questions. You just adapt to this culture, play by the rules.

Just as smiling is taught to be used abundantly and without reservation with everyone in the US, in many other countries it is taught to be used sparsely and carefully. Not because they are emotionless ice blocks, but rather because smiles in those parts have a different social role.

Smiles in many cultures are cherished as a precious gift, thoughtfully shared and very intentionally presented to those that undeniably deserve it: family and true friends.

Intriguingly, some participants in an attempt to decipher and better understand, wondered if constant smiling, a seemingly foolproof transmitter of good vibes, could also be a front used to mask true feelings. Is copious smiling so deceptively pleasant we mistaken it as a reflection of what goes on inside? Can the balminess of smiling derail us from seeing the deeper humanity behind it, stuff that may not be as pretty at a glance though beautiful in its vulnerability?

These ideas intertwined with another staple of American social conduct — small talk (sprinkled with an abundance of “thank yous”) — deserves a bit more reflection and a separate post.

In the end, all those immigrants culture shocked by an onslaught of smiling Americans agreed that after a while they not only got used to smiling more but loved it! Smiling, my participants say, eventually became second nature and made their everyday life and daily interactions so much more pleasant. Smiles finally became free for all! And it’s a good thing, especially knowing all kinds of great things we now know about the psychology of smiling, one of the key ingredients in the pursuit of happiness.

Now when they go back to visit their stone faced old country compatriots is the only time immigrants realize how much they have gotten accustomed to smiling in America. All of a sudden there is something jarring, awkward and unfriendly about the demeanor of the people back there. And surely the locals are just as equally freaked out by the newly minted Americans morphed into these human billboards of the undying American optimism, broad smile its unapologetic logo.

We can argue whether Americans smile more because their lives are in many ways more stable compared to the economically depressed, socially oppressed and war torn places around the world from which a lot of the non-smilers come.

But no matter its origin, this trademark social cue contributes to the American aura of positivity, optimism and hope not found in many other nations. Boiled down to the simplest (but by no means complete) formula, smiling leads to happiness, and happiness to positivity — a fruitful ground for daring exploration, advancements in innovation and overall excitement about life’s possibilities.

Still, smiling is one example of how no matter how intuitive and well intended a cultural trait may seem on the surface it can sometimes, funny enough, not be the easiest one to adapt to.

But smiling is also an example of many little things that make America a great place to live and be a part of, a reason why most of us stay. Unlike in many of our original countries, here we are in most daily interactions met with respect and basic acknowledgment of our humanity — a luxury one can only hope to occasionally encounter in many other countries.

As put by another study participant:

Here when you meet somebody for the first time, most suppose that you are a nice person. We are not used in Romania to smile if we don’t have a good reason, and when I came here it took me a while to adjust to people smiling and now I do the same and it’s nice.
If you grow up in a country where nobody smiles because there are no reasons to smile and you are not taught that it’s nice to smile, after years of that it’s difficult to change. Smiling gives you a nice feeling, although at first I was asking myself why? Is there a reason they smile and I don’t see it? I accepted it because I enjoyed it when someone talked to me, but it took a long time for me to do the same.
In Romania you only smile if you [are pursuing] a girl that you like or something really funny happens. It has to be something obvious, not just an [everyday] interaction. Even when I’d meet with my friends we’d go get a beer, talk about stuff, but we were very serious.
I now smile there like I do when I’m here and it’s much easier, people like it, everybody is opening up!

Adapting to a new culture is a long and complex process. If something as simple as a smile can offset a commotion in the mind already working tirelessly to understand the new rules and recalibrate the value system, how can we expect multilayered concepts such as democracy to catch on like the latest pop tune?

It is easy and misguided to mistaken the hesitation born out of largely temporary (though not necessarily short) disorientation, for an eternal and categorical opposition to the idea, be it smiling, women’s rights, secularism, or democracy itself. Instead of indulging in flabbergasted befuddlement let’s recognize the long haul acculturation calls for.

The human reaction to the immediate contact with a new culture is not called shock just for fun and giggles. As if rearranging the body parts, their functionality taking on completely new roles, immigrant thoughts go through a whirlwind of epic proportions ebbing and flowing in both length and intensity. Waiting for the dust to settle, the view to clear, the hearing to regain full capacity, takes utmost patience and understanding on all sides.

Only then can we hope that those smile-deprived newcomers discover the American smile for what it strives to be — a daily opportunity to give and receive kindness and compassion in a world that can never have enough of either. A cultural treasure worth embracing and spreading.
